• UK defeated over EU budget
• 48-hour strike called in Greece
• Greek 2013 budget published
• Photos: protests in Athens and Barcelona
• Eurozone unemployment at record high
fields.body:
7.31pm GMT

That's all, folks

Our Politics Live blog is covering all the reaction and analysis to tonight's vote on the EU Budget.

So (for the second time tonight) I"m going to say goodnight!

Updated at 7.31pm GMT

7.29pm GMT

Kate Hoey, one of the Labour MPs who called for an In-Out referendum this afternoon, just told Sky News that the government's defeat should trigger a thorough reassessment of Britain's position in Europe.

7.26pm GMT

Government loses vote over EU budget

Breaking: the UK government has been defeated over tonight's vote on the EU budget.

307 MPs voted in favour of an amendment that said the EU budget should be cut in real terms.

294 MPs opposed the motion.

Politically, that's a blow to David Cameron.

In terms of Europe, it doesn't make a huge difference in the short term -- Cameron can still argue for the EU budget to only rise in line with inflation (while the EC wants a inflation-busting increase).

It also shows that euroscepticism is alive, well and on the charge in Westminster, at a time when the push for European integration is raising new concerns over Britain's position, and future, in the EU.

7.13pm GMT

Some lobby journalists reckon the UK government may just survive the vote on the EU budget, although as I blogged at 5.28pm there was plenty of euroscepticism in the House of Commons tonight.

Updated at 7.13pm GMT

7.09pm GMT

Westminster MPs vote on EU budget

The other big news tonight is the vote in the House of Commons over the EU budget. MPs have just finished debating, and are voting now....

That's being covered minute-by-minute by our Politics Live blog, and speculation is growing that the government could lose. Many MPs have demanded that in the current economic crisis, any increase in the EU budget is unacceptable.

The results of the vote are due in just a few minutes...

6.46pm GMT

FT: Scale of Greece's problems laid bare

The Financial Times argues tonight that the economic projections in Greece's budget for 2013 (see 11.48am) are the final proof that it will miss the targets under its current bailout:

Here's the story: New debt forecasts dash Greece hopes

And here's a flavour:

The magnitude of Greece’s fiscal challenge was painted in sharp relief yesterday as Athens unveiled new budget projections exceeding the worst-case scenarios envisioned by international lenders when they agreed an €174bn rescue eight months ago.

Instead of Greece’s debt peaking at 167 per cent of economic output next year, as predicted in the March bailout agreement, it will hit 189 per cent and climb to 192 per cent in 2014, according to projections presented to the Greek parliament.

The new projections all but dash hopes Greek debt would come down to 120 per cent of GDP by 2020 – once held out as the standard for a manageable debt load – and senior EU officials acknowledged they may have to give Athens more leeway to hit that target under a revised rescue currently being negotiated.

Updated at 7.05pm GMT

6.32pm GMT

Consternation in Greece tonight

Our correspondent in Athens Helena Smith says while today’s Euro group’s assessment of the country’s fiscal progress (see 2.55pm) has been formally welcomed, Greek officials are also expressing consternation that the worst is far from over.

Helena writes:

The failure of senior cadres in both the socialist Pasok and Democratic Left parties to back the governing coalition’s endorsement of a major privatizations bill in parliament today has clearly unnerved officials.

One source at the finance minister conceded that the abstentions could be a precursor of the way the vote will go next week when the long-awaited €13.5bn austerity package is also put before the 300-seat House. “After today it’s not certain it will be passed even if that scenario is not one we want to talk about,” he said.

Evangelos Venizelos is now working around-the-clock to try and persuade his own MPs to back the measures but tensions are such that the party’s own survival is at stake.

Venizelos, the former finance minister, says the “most important negotiations will take place between Greece and its European partners [at the Eurogroup on November 12] and will finish in the wee hours of November 13,” over how to put Greece on a sustainable path and ensure growth.

6.29pm GMT

Protests in Portugal

There were protests in Lisbon today as the Portuguese parliament approved the 2013 budget. Here's a few snaps:

Updated at 6.29pm GMT

6.08pm GMT

Grombie watch

I mentioned this morning (see 7.57am) that JP Morgan has created a new term - Grimbo - to describe the limbo in which Greece is now trapped.

Well, regular reader James Wilkins has a better idea:

How about ‘Grombie’ for a country that is past saving ( as in zombie bank) Unfortunately the Eurozone favours zombie banks over Grombies.

Updated at 6.09pm GMT

5.59pm GMT

Some late bad news from Dublin, via Henry McDonald:

As darkness falls on Hallowe'en (an Irish invented festival by the way) in Dublin there are ghoulish warnings about job losses in the telecommunications industry.

Eircom - one of the biggest players in the internet and mobile phone sector in the Republic - has now confirmed that it is seeking 2,000 redundancies across the state.

It is not yet clear if these will be part of a voluntary redundancy scheme but with nearly 15 per cent of the Irish workforce already on the dole it is another nightmare for the Irish people and its government.

5.28pm GMT

British MPs debate EU budget

In Westminster, MPs are holding a fiery debate over the EU budget.

While David Cameron had won early plaudits for his insistence that the budget should be pegged to inflation, he now faces a battle with eurosceptic members of his own party who want an actual cut in real terms.

The idea of sending more precious pounds to Brussels has enraged Bill Cash, who just blashed Europe's approach to spending, saying:

The money comes from our constituents, it comes from taxpayers. It doesn't grow on trees.....And they don't understand that.

I hope that's clear to anyone who wondered how the monetary system worked....

Cash went on to urge Cameron to allow the rest of Europe to form a federal state, but to stand on the sidelines.

Cameron has tried to calm the situation, saying today that

At best we would like it [the budget] cut, at worst frozen

Anyway, the result of tonight's vote will depend on whether Labour decides to vote with the Tory rebels, which will itself depend on whether the parliamentary maths adds up.....

Kate Hoey, a Labour MP, is now arguing that parliament is behind public opinion over the issue of Europe, and believes an in-out referendum is needed.

Douglas Carswell, the Conservative MP who is pushing a private member's bill calling for a referendum, believes that parliament will vote in favour of cutting the EU budget.

Updated at 5.30pm GMT

4.56pm GMT

Protestors are gathering outside the Athens University this evening for a demonstration:

4.42pm GMT

Think tank news

Open Europe, the think tank we often quote in the blog, has opened a new office in Berlin today.

The goal is to "inject fresh thinking into the German debate about the future direction of the EU".

Here's some more details:

And ReDefine, another influential thinktank (run by Sony Kapoor), has also been busy:

Updated at 4.54pm GMT

4.32pm GMT

Here's a video clip about today's events in Greece.

4.08pm GMT

Protests in Athens and Barcelona - photos

Protests have been taking place in several European cities today.

In Athens, residents from towns in northwestern Greece gathered outside parliament and threw icecubes onto the road in a demonstration against a tax hike on heating fuel.

Here's a couple of photos:

Meanwhile, over in Barcelona a protest organised by unions resulted in demonstrators pushing into retail stores, and upsetting the shelves in Zara.

3.49pm GMT

Portugal approves budget

Over in Portugal, the Lisbon parliament has passed the 2013 budget, despite public anger over the austerity measures contained in it.

Now we wait to see if there is a legal battle over the programme (see 8.36am for more)

Updated at 3.49pm GMT

3.10pm GMT

On that eurogroup statement...

A few thoughts about the statement issued by the eurogroup (see 14.55pm)

1) The eurozone finance ministers don't believe Greece has reached a full and final deal with the troika, despite Antonis Samaras's comments yesterday that negotiations were over. They see "remaining issues"

2) It is not certain that the meeting on 12 November will deliver a deal on Greece, with ministers saying they will "seek to conclude" on the programme.

3) What happened to the idea of a meeting on 8 November, as the draft statement published by Dow Jones suggested? (see 1.21pm)

Updated at 3.37pm GMT

2.55pm GMT

Eurogroup statement on Greece

The Eurogroup has also issued a statement after their phone chat. And it appears that eurozone finance ministers have toned down the content compared to the draft version that Dow Jones had earlier (see 1.21pm)

Here's the text, attributed to Jean-Claude Juncker, president of the eurogroup:

The Eurogroup took note of the progress made towards a full staff level agreement between Greece and the Troika on updated programme conditionality, including ambitious and wide-ranging measures in the areas of fiscal consolidation, structural reforms, privatisation and financial sector stabilisation. We called on the Greek authorities to solve remaining issues so as to swiftly finalise the negotiations with the Troika institutions.

The Eurogroup expects to further discuss the Greek adjustment programme at its next regular meeting on 12 November on the basis of the relevant programme documentation and seek to conclude on the programme, subject to the completion of prior actions by the Greek authorities and of national procedures in Member States, in line with the established practice.

2.41pm GMT

Troika report into Greece not due until 11 November - Schäuble

One more line from Wolfgang Schäuble -- he told a news conference that euro zone finance ministers are unlikely to receive the troika's report on Greece before November 11th or 12th.

Safely after the US elections, in other words.

Schäuble also repeated his opposition to public creditors taking a haircut on their Greek bonds, arguing that this would be illegal (as they'd be monetising Greece's debts).

Updated at 2.44pm GMT

2.36pm GMT

Schäuble speaks

The eurozone finance ministers have indeed finished their teleconference, and Germany's Wolfgang Schäuble has lost little time in briefing the media.

Reuters has the snaps:

• SCHAEUBLE SAYS AFTER PHONE CALL WITH EURO ZONE FINANCE MINISTERS THAT THERE IS CONSIDERABLE PROGRESS ON GREECE BUT NO DEAL YET

• SCHAEUBLE SAYS NO CONCRETE NEGOTIATIONS WITH CYPRUS YET, WILL PROBABLY NOT START UNTIL 2013

2.13pm GMT

Eurozone finance ministers have concluded their discussions on Greece, according to the FT's Peter Spiegel, who anticipates an official statement shortly (not just the draft version which hit the newswires this morning)

2.11pm GMT

48-hour Greek strike called

Back to Greece, where the country's two biggest union groups have called a new two-day strike for next week.

GSEE (which represents the private sector) and ADEDY (the public sector union) jointly announced a 48h strike starting on Tuesday 6th November.

The stoppage is an attempt to prevent MPs approving the €13.5bn package of austerity measures, when it comes to a vote next week.

Ilias Iliopoulos, general secretary of ADEDY, said:

We will strike to stop the measures from being voted in parliament.

We won't allow the government to hurt Greek people any more.

1.59pm GMT

Relief for Irish taxpayers

Amid the gloom in Greece, we have some good news for hard-pressed Irish taxpayers - from the bank that alost bankrupted Ireland.

The cost of rescuing the now-nationalised Anglo Irish Bank will now be €25 billion, the chairman of the Irish Bank Resolution Corporation Alan Dukes disclosed today.

This figure is far lower than previous estimates for the cost of bailing out Anglo which ranged from €29 to €34bn euros.

As Henry McDonald, our correspondent in Dublin, explains:

All this matters to Europe because the Republic's government is seeking funds from the EU to ease the burden of the country's banking debts.

Dukes, a former minister in a previous Fine Gael-Labour coalition, told the Irish parliament's powerful Finance Committee that the IBRC (formerly Anglo Irish Bank) has cut staff numbers at the now state owned bank by 50% from its peak level in 2008.

While the cost of ressurecting one Irish zombie bank is less than first feared another foreign bank in the Irish market has some grim news about consumer spending coming up to Christmas.

The KBC bank along with the Economic and Social Research Institute has found that consumer sentiment is barely up from a low point in September.

In their montly snapshot of consumer's intentions that just over 60% of Irish consumers were optimistic about their spending power.

The bank and the ESRI predict another tough Christmas period for shoppers and retailers alike, coming as it does in the same month as yet another austerity, cost cutting budget.

1.49pm GMT

Wall Street reopens

Over in New York, trading has begun on Wall Street after the two-day suspension caused by Superstorm Sandy.

Mayor Michael Bloomberg rang the opening bell, to more enthusiastic applause than usual from the assembled traders (I thought, anyway).

Despite the devastation caused to parts of the east coast of the USA, the markets are calm with the blue chip index rising in early trading: 

Dow Jones Industrial Average: up 64 points at 13171, +0.49%

Updated at 3.01pm GMT

1.21pm GMT

Eurogroup draft statement on Greece

A draft statement from the Eurogroup has emerged, as finance ministers hold their telephone conference call

They say that they are ready to call a meeting on 8 November to consider the situation in Greece,as long as "documentation" is available showing Greece has complied with its obligations.

They would then meet again on 12 November to formally approve its next aid tranche (worth €31.5bn).

The statement also urges Greece to take the "prior actions" it has agreed to.

The call began shortly after Greece published its 2013 budget, which contained new economic forecasts that were even less rosy than a month ago (see 11.48).

[the draft statement came via Dow Jones, btw - the call appears to be continuing]

Updated at 2.07pm GMT

12.54pm GMT

Greek MPs approve privatisation bill

The word from Greece is that the parliament has now passed a bill on privatisations, after what Dow Jones newswires dubbed a 'fractious' session.

The voting saw 15 socialist members of the coalition fail to support the party line, though, according to Theodora Oikonomides.

Updated at 1.21pm GMT

12.36pm GMT

Greek GDP forecasts

On GDP, the Greek government's medium-term economic plan plots a return to growth in 2014.

2013: -4.5%

2014: +0.2%

2015: +2.5%

2016: +3.5%

That's from the Greek 2013 budget (see 11.48am onwards):

City traders and economists are sceptical about the forecasts in today's budget, as these tweets show:

Updated at 12.41pm GMT

12.25pm GMT

Greek GDP and Unemployment forecasts

The 2013 Greek budget predicts an unemployment rate of 22.8% in 2013, falling to 21.4% in 2014, 19.7% in 2015, and 17.1% in 2016.

However, today's eurozone jobless data shows that the Greek jobless rate hit 25.1% in July, so the targets are clearly extremely stretching.

Updated at 12.35pm GMT

12.01pm GMT

Key points in Greece's budget

Blogger and commentator Yiannis Mouzakis has rapidly analysed the 2013 Greek budget and tweeted the key charts, along with helpful explanations in Engish.

Updated at 12.04pm GMT

11.48am GMT

Greek 2013 Budget paints grim picture

Over in Greece, the details of the 2013 Budget are being digested after finance minister Yannis Stournaras presented them to MPs this morning.

The mood is extremely sombre, as the budget is packed with fresh evidence that Greece's economy is on a sharp downward spiral.

Here are the key points:

• the budget predicts that government debt will hit 189.1% of gross domestic product in 2013. The budget deficit is forecast at 5.2% of GDP, compared with the 4.2% deficit predicted a month ago.

• The revisions mean that Greece no longer expects to post a surplus excluding debt costs of 1.1% of GDP next year. It now only expects a primary surplus of 0.4%.

• The budget also forecasts the Greek economy contracting by 4.5% in 2013, from 3.8% in the previous draft. That means that Greek GDP will have slumped by 21.5% since 2008 by the end of next year. A true depression.

The full budget is online here (in Greek), and here's the front page:

Reaction to follow....

Updated at 6.42pm GMT

10.58am GMT

Analysts fear jobless rate will keep climbing

City economists believe eurozone unemployment will continue to climb as the region's economic crisis continues. Here's some early reaction:

Ben May of Capital Economics:

With survey measures suggesting that firms are becoming more reluctant to hire, the eurozone unemployment rate looks set to rise further, placing more pressure on struggling households.

Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight:

The eurozone unemployment data for September are both disappointing and worrying... and highlights that eurozone labour markets remain under serious pressure from ongoing weakened economic activity and low business confidence

Updated at 11.54am GMT

10.27am GMT

Jobless rate by countries

As usual, the unemployment data gives a clear picture of the economic divergences across Europe -- with Spain's jobless rate nearly six times higher than Austria.

The lowest rates:

Austria: 4.4%

Luxembourg: 5.2%

Germany: 5.4%

The Netherlands: 5.4%

The highest rates:

Spain: 25.8%

Greece: 25.1% (for July: September's data isn't available yet)

Latvia: 15.9% (for Q3)

Portugal: 15.7%

The true picture in Greece is probably worse, as a growing number of workers are still officially employed but have not been paid for some time.

Updated at 10.52am GMT

10.10am GMT

There are now 18.49 million people out of work in the euro area, with an extra 146,000 joining the ranks of the unemployed in September (Eurostat reported).

Across the whole European Union, there are now 25.751 million men and women out of work, up by 169,000 since August.

Updated at 10.21am GMT

10.07am GMT

Get the report here

You can download the official release on eurozone unemployment from Eurostat's web site (pdf).

Updated at 10.08am GMT

10.02am GMT

Eurozone jobless rate hits new high

Breaking: the Eurozone unemployment rate has hit a new record high.

Eurostat has reported that the jobless total hit 11.6% in September,.

That's up from 11.5% in August - which has itself been revised up from the previous reading of 11.4%.

Further evidence that the euro jobless crisis is accelerating.

More to follow!

Updated at 10.03am GMT

9.36am GMT

Over in Greece, finance minister Yiannis Stournaras is submitting the 2013 budget to parliament.

Updated at 9.38am GMT

8.58am GMT

Rajoy: EU needs to move faster

Interesting comments from Spain's prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, this morning.

Speaking in the Madrid parliament, Rajoy said that the eurozone crisis could only be solved through solutions at domestic and regional level.

Rajoy, who has been prevaricating over whether to ask for financial help for weeks, then went on to criticise the EU for its own slow progress.

Here are the key quotes:

Overcoming the crisis depends on national reforms but also European policies

The European Union is moving, but at a pace that can seem desperately slow to some of us.

Rajoy may have been thinking of the plans for a new single banking supervisor, which will not be fully operational until well into 2013...

8.51am GMT

Eurozone jobless rate expected to hit new high

Today's jobless figures for the eurozone, due out at 10am GMT, could make grim reading, my colleague Julia Kollewe reports:

The unemployment rate is expected to have risen again, to a record 11.5%. In Italy, the rate is forecast to hit 10.8% from 10.7%.

Updated at 8.51am GMT

8.36am GMT

Portugal faces legal fight over austerity budget

It's also a key day in Portugal, where the Lisbon parliament will vote on its latest austerity package, and probably spark a legal battle.

The 2013 budget includes hefty increases in income tax, as well as higher property taxes and a levy on financial transactions.

The budget has been dogged by legal challenges and public protests. A plan to hit workers with a massive increase in social security payment was abandoned after mass protests, while a plan to cut civil servants' benefits was blocked by Portugal's constitutional court.

Despite public anger, the reworked budget is likely to go through.

However, political experts say the new budget is almost certain to be challenged in court.

Pedro Magalhaes, political scientist at the Social Sciences Institute of the Lisbon University, said:

If the court finds something unconstitutional, it could still be something relatively easy to fix, or alternatively it could shoot down the budget and cause a political crisis.

Here's the full story: Portugal to introduce higher taxes to meet EU bailout terms

Updated at 8.57am GMT

8.23am GMT

Matina Stevis of the Wall Street Journal confirms that we shouldn't expect finance ministers to take a decision on whether to grant Greece more time to hit its debt sustainability targets:

7.57am GMT

Grimbo time is here, by golly

With Greece seemingly clinging onto its place in the eurozone for longer than some had expected, talk of Grexit (Citi's slightly clunky term for a Greek exit) has faded away.

Instead, JP Morgan have come up with a new term: Grimbo.

Jamie McGeever of Reuters explains:

This is not a welcome development, frankly. But how long until Grimbo is cancelled?

7.50am GMT

Finance ministers to 'take stock' of Greek situation

Eurozone finance ministers are not expected to take any big decision on Greece on this morning's conference call.

EU officials have been briefing that the talks will consider Greece's compliance with its aid programme

One told Reuters:

It will be just taking stock of the situation regarding the Greek assistance programme. There will be no decisions since there is no Troika report yet.

The call could still be interesting, though, as national governments are likely to leak the details, so we should discover who's taking a particularly hard line and who is open to granting Athens more time.

7.25am GMT

Eurozone finance ministers to discuss Greece

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the eurozone crisis, and other events in the world economy.

Greece is in the spotlight today. Finance ministers from across the eurozone are due to hold a teleconference call this morning (at 11.30am GMT) to discuss Athens' progress on its performance against its aid targets.

The call comes as the political battle over Greece's €13.5bn austerity package intensifies. Having concluded its negotiations with the troika on Tuesday (see yesterday's blog), the government must now get the controversial and unpopular programme through parliament.

Encouragingly for prime minister Antonis Samaras, the indications are that one junior partner - the left-wing Pasok - will support the package. According to Reuters overnight, "an overwhelming majority of Greek Socialist lawmakers" have agreed to support it.

"The overwhelming majority of Pasok lawmakers are in favour of the package," one of the party officials said, adding that just two of the 33 Pasok lawmakers would vote against the package, while another two had yet to decide.

That would mean that Democratic Left, the third party in the coalition, could not block the austerity package. It is still refusing to support the labour market reforms which the troika insists on.

There should be action in the Greek parliament today, with MPs due to vote on a privatisation bill and start consider the 2013 budget.

And we're also expecting protests on the streets of Athens tonight, as unions continue to demonstrate against Samaras's government and the troika.

And with new eurozone unemployment data due this morning, and the Portuguese parliament voting on its own austerity budget, we have a lively day ahead....

Updated at 8.11am GMT

Some late bad news from Dublin, via Henry McDonald: As darkness falls on Hallowe'en (an Irish invented festival by the way) in Dublin there are ghoulish warnings about job losses in the telecommunications industry. Eircom - one of the biggest players in the internet and mobile phone sector in the Republic - has now confirmed that it is seeking 2,000 redundancies across the state. It is not yet clear if these will be part of a voluntary redundancy scheme but with nearly 15 per cent of the Irish workforce already on the dole it is another nightmare for the Irish people and its government. In Westminster, MPs are holding a fiery debate over the EU budget. While David Cameron had won early plaudits for his insistence that the budget should be pegged to inflation, he now faces a battle with eurosceptic members of his own party who want an actual cut in real terms. The idea of sending more precious pounds to Brussels has enraged Bill Cash, who just blashed Europe's approach to spending, saying: The money comes from our constituents, it comes from taxpayers. It doesn't grow on trees.....And they don't understand that. I hope that's clear to anyone who wondered how the monetary system worked.... Cash went on to urge Cameron to allow the rest of Europe to form a federal state, but to stand on the sidelines. Cameron has tried to calm the situation, saying today that At best we would like it [the budget] cut, at worst frozen Anyway, the result of tonight's vote will depend on whether Labour decides to vote with the Tory rebels, which will itself depend on whether the parliamentary maths adds up..... Kate Hoey, a Labour MP, is now arguing that parliament is behind public opinion over the issue of Europe, and believes an in-out referendum is needed. Douglas Carswell, the Conservative MP who is pushing a private member's bill calling for a referendum, believes that parliament will vote in favour of cutting the EU budget. Protestors are gathering outside the Athens University this evening for a demonstration: Open Europe, the think tank we often quote in the blog, has opened a new office in Berlin today. The goal is to "inject fresh thinking into the German debate about the future direction of the EU". Here's some more details: And ReDefine, another influential thinktank (run by Sony Kapoor), has also been busy: Here's a video clip about today's events in Greece. Protests have been taking place in several European cities today. In Athens, residents from towns in northwestern Greece gathered outside parliament and threw icecubes onto the road in a demonstration against a tax hike on heating fuel. Here's a couple of photos: Meanwhile, over in Barcelona a protest organised by unions resulted in demonstrators pushing into retail stores, and upsetting the shelves in Zara. Over in Portugal, the Lisbon parliament has passed the 2013 budget, despite public anger over the austerity measures contained in it. Now we wait to see if there is a legal battle over the programme (see 8.36am for more) A few thoughts about the statement issued by the eurogroup (see 14.55pm) 1) The eurozone finance ministers don't believe Greece has reached a full and final deal with the troika, despite Antonis Samaras's comments yesterday that negotiations were over. They see "remaining issues" 2) It is not certain that the meeting on 12 November will deliver a deal on Greece, with ministers saying they will "seek to conclude" on the programme. 3) What happened to the idea of a meeting on 8 November, as the draft statement published by Dow Jones suggested? (see 1.21pm) The Eurogroup has also issued a statement after their phone chat. And it appears that eurozone finance ministers have toned down the content compared to the draft version that Dow Jones had earlier (see 1.21pm) Here's the text, attributed to Jean-Claude Juncker, president of the eurogroup: The Eurogroup took note of the progress made towards a full staff level agreement between Greece and the Troika on updated programme conditionality, including ambitious and wide-ranging measures in the areas of fiscal consolidation, structural reforms, privatisation and financial sector stabilisation. We called on the Greek authorities to solve remaining issues so as to swiftly finalise the negotiations with the Troika institutions. The Eurogroup expects to further discuss the Greek adjustment programme at its next regular meeting on 12 November on the basis of the relevant programme documentation and seek to conclude on the programme, subject to the completion of prior actions by the Greek authorities and of national procedures in Member States, in line with the established practice. One more line from Wolfgang Schäuble -- he told a news conference that euro zone finance ministers are unlikely to receive the troika's report on Greece before November 11th or 12th. Safely after the US elections, in other words. Schäuble also repeated his opposition to public creditors taking a haircut on their Greek bonds, arguing that this would be illegal (as they'd be monetising Greece's debts). The eurozone finance ministers have indeed finished their teleconference, and Germany's Wolfgang Schäuble has lost little time in briefing the media. Reuters has the snaps: • SCHAEUBLE SAYS AFTER PHONE CALL WITH EURO ZONE FINANCE MINISTERS THAT THERE IS CONSIDERABLE PROGRESS ON GREECE BUT NO DEAL YET • SCHAEUBLE SAYS NO CONCRETE NEGOTIATIONS WITH CYPRUS YET, WILL PROBABLY NOT START UNTIL 2013 Eurozone finance ministers have concluded their discussions on Greece, according to the FT's Peter Spiegel, who anticipates an official statement shortly (not just the draft version which hit the newswires this morning) Back to Greece, where the country's two biggest union groups have called a new two-day strike for next week. GSEE (which represents the private sector) and ADEDY (the public sector union) jointly announced a 48h strike starting on Tuesday 6th November. The stoppage is an attempt to prevent MPs approving the €13.5bn package of austerity measures, when it comes to a vote next week. Ilias Iliopoulos, general secretary of ADEDY, said: We will strike to stop the measures from being voted in parliament. We won't allow the government to hurt Greek people any more. Amid the gloom in Greece, we have some good news for hard-pressed Irish taxpayers - from the bank that alost bankrupted Ireland. The cost of rescuing the now-nationalised Anglo Irish Bank will now be €25 billion, the chairman of the Irish Bank Resolution Corporation Alan Dukes disclosed today. This figure is far lower than previous estimates for the cost of bailing out Anglo which ranged from €29 to €34bn euros. As Henry McDonald, our correspondent in Dublin, explains: All this matters to Europe because the Republic's government is seeking funds from the EU to ease the burden of the country's banking debts. Dukes, a former minister in a previous Fine Gael-Labour coalition, told the Irish parliament's powerful Finance Committee that the IBRC (formerly Anglo Irish Bank) has cut staff numbers at the now state owned bank by 50% from its peak level in 2008. While the cost of ressurecting one Irish zombie bank is less than first feared another foreign bank in the Irish market has some grim news about consumer spending coming up to Christmas. The KBC bank along with the Economic and Social Research Institute has found that consumer sentiment is barely up from a low point in September. In their montly snapshot of consumer's intentions that just over 60% of Irish consumers were optimistic about their spending power. The bank and the ESRI predict another tough Christmas period for shoppers and retailers alike, coming as it does in the same month as yet another austerity, cost cutting budget. Over in New York, trading has begun on Wall Street after the two-day suspension caused by Superstorm Sandy. Mayor Michael Bloomberg rang the opening bell, to more enthusiastic applause than usual from the assembled traders (I thought, anyway). Despite the devastation caused to parts of the east coast of the USA, the markets are calm with the blue chip index rising in early trading: Dow Jones Industrial Average: up 64 points at 13171, +0.49% A draft statement from the Eurogroup has emerged, as finance ministers hold their telephone conference call They say that they are ready to call a meeting on 8 November to consider the situation in Greece,as long as "documentation" is available showing Greece has complied with its obligations. They would then meet again on 12 November to formally approve its next aid tranche (worth €31.5bn). The statement also urges Greece to take the "prior actions" it has agreed to. The call began shortly after Greece published its 2013 budget, which contained new economic forecasts that were even less rosy than a month ago (see 11.48). [the draft statement came via Dow Jones, btw - the call appears to be continuing] The word from Greece is that the parliament has now passed a bill on privatisations, after what Dow Jones newswires dubbed a 'fractious' session. The voting saw 15 socialist members of the coalition fail to support the party line, though, according to Theodora Oikonomides. On GDP, the Greek government's medium-term economic plan plots a return to growth in 2014. 2013: -4.5% 2014: +0.2% 2015: +2.5% 2016: +3.5% That's from the Greek 2013 budget (see 11.48am onwards): City traders and economists are sceptical about the forecasts in today's budget, as these tweets show: The 2013 Greek budget predicts an unemployment rate of 22.8% in 2013, falling to 21.4% in 2014, 19.7% in 2015, and 17.1% in 2016. However, today's eurozone jobless data shows that the Greek jobless rate hit 25.1% in July, so the targets are clearly extremely stretching. Blogger and commentator Yiannis Mouzakis has rapidly analysed the 2013 Greek budget and tweeted the key charts, along with helpful explanations in Engish. Over in Greece, the details of the 2013 Budget are being digested after finance minister Yannis Stournaras presented them to MPs this morning. The mood is extremely sombre, as the budget is packed with fresh evidence that Greece's economy is on a sharp downward spiral. Here are the key points: • the budget predicts that government debt will hit 189.1% of gross domestic product in 2013. The budget deficit is forecast at 5.2% of GDP, compared with the 4.2% deficit predicted a month ago. • The revisions mean that Greece no longer expects to post a surplus excluding debt costs of 1.1% of GDP next year. It now only expects a primary surplus of 0.4%. • The budget also forecasts the Greek economy contracting by 4.5% in 2013, from 3.8% in the previous draft. That means that Greek GDP will have slumped by 21.5% since 2008 by the end of next year. A true depression. The full budget is online here (in Greek), and here's the front page: Reaction to follow.... City economists believe eurozone unemployment will continue to climb as the region's economic crisis continues. Here's some early reaction: Ben May of Capital Economics: With survey measures suggesting that firms are becoming more reluctant to hire, the eurozone unemployment rate looks set to rise further, placing more pressure on struggling households. Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight: The eurozone unemployment data for September are both disappointing and worrying... and highlights that eurozone labour markets remain under serious pressure from ongoing weakened economic activity and low business confidence As usual, the unemployment data gives a clear picture of the economic divergences across Europe -- with Spain's jobless rate nearly six times higher than Austria. The lowest rates: Austria: 4.4% Luxembourg: 5.2% Germany: 5.4% The Netherlands: 5.4% The highest rates: Spain: 25.8% Greece: 25.1% (for July: September's data isn't available yet) Latvia: 15.9% (for Q3) Portugal: 15.7% The true picture in Greece is probably worse, as a growing number of workers are still officially employed but have not been paid for some time. There are now 18.49 million people out of work in the euro area, with an extra 146,000 joining the ranks of the unemployed in September (Eurostat reported). Across the whole European Union, there are now 25.751 million men and women out of work, up by 169,000 since August. You can download the official release on eurozone unemployment from Eurostat's web site (pdf). Breaking: the Eurozone unemployment rate has hit a new record high. Eurostat has reported that the jobless total hit 11.6% in September,. That's up from 11.5% in August - which has itself been revised up from the previous reading of 11.4%. Further evidence that the euro jobless crisis is accelerating. More to follow! Over in Greece, finance minister Yiannis Stournaras is submitting the 2013 budget to parliament. Interesting comments from Spain's prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, this morning. Speaking in the Madrid parliament, Rajoy said that the eurozone crisis could only be solved through solutions at domestic and regional level. Rajoy, who has been prevaricating over whether to ask for financial help for weeks, then went on to criticise the EU for its own slow progress. Here are the key quotes: Overcoming the crisis depends on national reforms but also European policies The European Union is moving, but at a pace that can seem desperately slow to some of us. Rajoy may have been thinking of the plans for a new single banking supervisor, which will not be fully operational until well into 2013... Today's jobless figures for the eurozone, due out at 10am GMT, could make grim reading, my colleague Julia Kollewe reports: The unemployment rate is expected to have risen again, to a record 11.5%. In Italy, the rate is forecast to hit 10.8% from 10.7%. It's also a key day in Portugal, where the Lisbon parliament will vote on its latest austerity package, and probably spark a legal battle. The 2013 budget includes hefty increases in income tax, as well as higher property taxes and a levy on financial transactions. The budget has been dogged by legal challenges and public protests. A plan to hit workers with a massive increase in social security payment was abandoned after mass protests, while a plan to cut civil servants' benefits was blocked by Portugal's constitutional court. Despite public anger, the reworked budget is likely to go through. However, political experts say the new budget is almost certain to be challenged in court. Pedro Magalhaes, political scientist at the Social Sciences Institute of the Lisbon University, said: If the court finds something unconstitutional, it could still be something relatively easy to fix, or alternatively it could shoot down the budget and cause a political crisis. Here's the full story: Portugal to introduce higher taxes to meet EU bailout terms Matina Stevis of the Wall Street Journal confirms that we shouldn't expect finance ministers to take a decision on whether to grant Greece more time to hit its debt sustainability targets: With Greece seemingly clinging onto its place in the eurozone for longer than some had expected, talk of Grexit (Citi's slightly clunky term for a Greek exit) has faded away. Instead, JP Morgan have come up with a new term: Grimbo. Jamie McGeever of Reuters explains: This is not a welcome development, frankly. But how long until Grimbo is cancelled? Eurozone finance ministers are not expected to take any big decision on Greece on this morning's conference call. EU officials have been briefing that the talks will consider Greece's compliance with its aid programme One told Reuters: It will be just taking stock of the situation regarding the Greek assistance programme. There will be no decisions since there is no Troika report yet. The call could still be interesting, though, as national governments are likely to leak the details, so we should discover who's taking a particularly hard line and who is open to granting Athens more time. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the eurozone crisis, and other events in the world economy. Greece is in the spotlight today. Finance ministers from across the eurozone are due to hold a teleconference call this morning (at 11.30am GMT) to discuss Athens' progress on its performance against its aid targets. The call comes as the political battle over Greece's €13.5bn austerity package intensifies. Having concluded its negotiations with the troika on Tuesday (see yesterday's blog), the government must now get the controversial and unpopular programme through parliament. Encouragingly for prime minister Antonis Samaras, the indications are that one junior partner - the left-wing Pasok - will support the package. According to Reuters overnight, "an overwhelming majority of Greek Socialist lawmakers" have agreed to support it. "The overwhelming majority of Pasok lawmakers are in favour of the package," one of the party officials said, adding that just two of the 33 Pasok lawmakers would vote against the package, while another two had yet to decide. That would mean that Democratic Left, the third party in the coalition, could not block the austerity package. It is still refusing to support the labour market reforms which the troika insists on. There should be action in the Greek parliament today, with MPs due to vote on a privatisation bill and start consider the 2013 budget. And we're also expecting protests on the streets of Athens tonight, as unions continue to demonstrate against Samaras's government and the troika. And with new eurozone unemployment data due this morning, and the Portuguese parliament voting on its own austerity budget, we have a lively day ahead....

webTitle: UK retailers buoyed by October sales growth

fields.bodyText: Consumers shrugged off concerns about the state of their finances to spend more freely in the shops last month, according to two surveys providing mixed messages about the state of the economy. Hopes that the UK might be on the road to recovery were boosted by the latest snapshot of high street spending from the CBI showing the strongest retail sales growth since the summer coupled with a belief among shops and stores that business in November would also be brisk. But a separate report from GfK showed already fragile consumer confidence weakening by two points to -30 as the short-term fillip from the Olympics faded. Nick Moon, Managing Director of Social Research at GfK, said: "Just as the economy moves out of recession consumer confidence dips again. While we are not quite back to the levels of this time last year, the index has not been this low in six months. "While the Olympics are thought to have boosted GDP in the last quarter, the late Summer boost in consumer sentiment has now faded. The government will be concerned that the economic bounce will follow a similar path and deflate during the Autumn." Moon added: "The fragility of the recovery is underlined by the fact that people are more worried about their own financial situation over the next 12 months. This certainly doesn't suggest there will be a spending boom on the back of the official emergence from recession." The CBI survey showed consumers responding to falling inflation by spending far more in October than had been expected. Almost half of retailers questioned (47%) said business was up last month on a year earlier, while 17% said sales were down. The balance of +30 points was the highest since June, when spending was lifted by the extra bank holiday for the Queen's diamond jubilee. Retailers were confident that business would remain brisk in November as the build-up to the key Christmas period began. Anna Leach, the CBI's head of economic analysis, said: "It is great news that last month's sales growth has continued into October, at a much faster pace than expected, and that this momentum is expected to continue next month too. "Falling inflation has somewhat eased pressures on family budgets, so that households are a little more willing to spend. But there's still a risk that ongoing uncertainty over the global economic outlook could dent consumer confidence, hitting prospects for the retail sector, while the scope for inflation to fall further is limited." The CBI said there was an across-the-board pickup in spending, led by clothes stores and furniture and carpets outlets. Clothing posted its first year-on-year sales growth in three months, while supermarkets also reported the sixth consecutive annual increase in volumes. Despite the sales growth, retailers still said trade was poor for the time of year. Of the 69 retailers polled, 16% said activity was good for the time of year while 23% said it was disappointing. The balance of –7 points was the least negative since April, the employers' organisation said.
